awd_titl_txt: Conference: Understanding Democracy, Elections, and Political Accountability
awd_abstract_narration:
This “Understanding Democracy, Elections, and Political Accountability” conference assesses how an important high court decision affects access to the ballot, election administration, and the exercise of the right to vote in the ten years after the decision. During the conference, twelve to 15 conference participants present and discuss papers and participate in translational contributions through community-based outreach. The conference will provide a 10-year retrospective social science examination of the effects of legal changes to voting procedures on voting rights protections and voter participation that will be useful for political scientists, sociologists, lawyers, and community groups. Topics of the conference include election law, voting rights, high court decisions related to voting rights, redistricting, electoral participation, and democratic accountability. The conference is organized by scholars from a MSI, a HBCU, and a PWI. Participants include the organizing committee, at least nine junior and senior scholars from across political science and legal academia, undergraduate and graduate students, and local community-of-interest experts. The conference also includes public-facing engagement with the Jackson, Mississippi community.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this grant was to convene scholars to produce an edited volume that examines the impact of the US Supreme Court’s Shelby County v. Holder decision on voting rights in former Confederate States--states that were largely covered by the preclearance provisions of the Voting Rights Act.  We used our grant money to convene an initial conference in Jackson, Mississippi in June 2023.  At this conference, which was held at the COFO (Congress of Federated Organizations—the organizing hub of 1963’s Freedom Summer) office, chapter authors met with local community activists and legal scholars and practitioners to gain insights to help them as they prepared their scholarly chapters.  Authors then presented their work in organized panels at the annual meetings of the Southern Political Science Association and the National Conference of Black Political Scientists in January and March 2024, respectively. 

We are currently in the process of preparing the chapters presented at the conferences into an edited volume.  There will be a chapter devoted to each former Confederate state, and authors consider the impacts of changes to voting laws in each state that took place subsequent to the Supreme Court’s decision. We plan on submitting a book proposal in summer 2024, with the hopes of publishing the edited volume in 2025 or 2026.


Last Modified: 07/13/2024
Modified by: Andra N Gillespie
